I saved these for last because this is my first time doing this big of a job and I have no idea what I am doing. No matter how hard I torque them, these bolts will not come out! >why won't these bolts come out? They are NOT rusted. replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text: >>3525444Yea its worth while and it might have you shooting more in the long run. You might even start deving too. Look into slide copiers and mirrorless cameras as well. They can be a surefire way to get good results and something like negative lab pro makes inverting color neg even easier.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text: >>3525686Will actually keep that in mind

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text: All DIYing with film is trading your time for money, while gaining more control over the results and methods. To save money first, you'd be talking like 5-7€ per roll, which'd take you about 40-45 minutes to scan on a flatbed. So not really worth the time above minimum wage, but then we start considering that the lowliest flatbed typically spits out 16-bit TIFFs which you can import into Darktable and have your way with, not 8-bit Instagram-ready JPEGs that some pimply-faced youth slapped some "clarity" and "grain" onto. Do the math, how many rolls does it take for the scanner to have paid for itself in lab costs.Same with dev, except your choice of chemistry and it's done in about half an hour of effort per two or three rolls, and two hours for them to dry.Same with bulkloading at some 20€ saved per 30½m.Same with making your own photo paper and/or dry plates.

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text: >>3525660For drum level scan quality and with a decent budget, I'd consider something like a S1R, high-end macro lens and custom holders for film. The resolution should be enough for anything up to 4x5, by tensioning film in the air instead of flattening it on glass you can avoid wet mounting, so overall it should be way less of a PITA than a drum scanner, the only problem is that you need a fucking mechanical engineering degree to make the holders.

text: No really, why haven't sonic games been able to make the jump to 3d without fucking absolutely everything up?

replies.name: Anonymous
replies.text: Because Sonic works best with very large levels and lots of routes, so you can go fast while still having time to process what's happening, and no matter what direction you pick you're still advancing. In the era that Sonic made the jump to 3D, creating something on that scale wasn't really technologically possible, so they had to impose a lot of restrictions. Levels were much smaller, most things needed automatic lockons or other mechanics to keep the players on track or they'd get lost instantly. Now that technology has advanced, those restrictions are still in place as they're seen as the way 3D Sonic is supposed to be.
